title: RFC1123 Compliant InternetDomainName Test Cases
body:
RFC1123 compliant InternetDomainName test cases

Add tests to prove URLs with leading digits are valid and containing only digits are valid.
#1872 was resolved at some point from 2014 to now without the issue getting closed. This PR adds test cases proving this issue can be closed. 

Some sample real domains from related to these tests would be [www.9gag.com](https://www.9gag.com/) and [www.9292.nl](https://www.9292.nl/)

title: [FeatureRequest] Add method Lists.partitionEven

labels.name: type=addition
labels.description: A new feature

body:
Dear guys,

Lists.partition is very useful. But sometime I need partition list evenly.

For example, I have a list `['a','b','c','d','e','f','g','h','i','j','k']`

Using `List.partition(list, 3)`, the result is 
```json
[
['a','b','c']
,['d','e', 'f']
, ['g','h','i']
, ['j', 'k']
]
```

I expect using `List.partitionEven(list, 3)`, the result should be 
```json
[
['a','b','c','d']
,['e','f','g','h']
,['i','j','k']
]
```

The use case for it is that when I have 3 thread to process the list, by using `partitionEven(list, 3)`, the 3 thread can process data even.

Thanks a lot!

title: Fix "Apache License, Version 2.0" spelling
body:
There are many Java libraries licensed under "Apache License, Version 2.0" that do not use its official spelling.
This causes issues like https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MPIR-382: with every library defining its own spelling, it's difficult in large projects to have a clear view of all licenses in use.
This PR changes the license spelling to the official one, as advised by Maven developers.

title: Define project build source encoding as UTF-8
body:
At build time the following warning appears:
`[WARNING] Using platform encoding (UTF-8 actually) to copy filtered resources, i.e. build is platform dependent!
`

Defining a project build source encoding removes the warning and can prevent platform dependent issues in the future.

Fix summary by maven [here](http://maven.apache.org/general.html#encoding-warning) and [here](https://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-resources-plugin/examples/encoding.html)

title: ImmutableEnumSet should implement ImmutableSortedSet
body: Since an `ImmutableEnumSet`'s delegate will always implement `SortedSet`, so should the `ImmutableEnumSet` itself be one. Then `ImmutableSortedSet.copyOf` would be able to return one for optimization, as `ImmutableSet.copyOf` already does.

title: Upgrade maven dependency plugin - security upgrade
body:
Maven dependency plugin has a dependency on plexus-archiver.
Plexus-archiver is vulnerable to the Zip Slip vulnerability ([CVE-2018-1002200](https://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-1002200/)) in versions prior to 3.4.1 & 3.6.0 ([reference](https://maven.apache.org/security-plexus-archiver.html)).
Maven-dependency-plugin version [3.1.1](https://blogs.apache.org/maven/entry/apache-maven-dependency-plugin-version1) upgrades to plexus-archiver [3.6.0](https://github.com/codehaus-plexus/plexus-archiver/blob/master/ReleaseNotes.md#plexus-archiver-360)
Versions bypassed:

Make extending of ContiguousSet possible

labels.name: type=enhancement
labels.description: Make an existing feature better

body:
I have to place `ContiguousSet` extensions into the same package due to `package-private` restrictions of the constructor. I understand that this is a choice of a design that allows empty contiguous set to be returned from the create static method. Binary compatibility of course suffers if the constructor would be changed to `protected` but I'm not sure if that change would be necessarily backwards incompatible in a breaking manner.

* * *

Here a gist (lacking a better name for the time being) of a use case where this change would be welcomed. 

This one tries to circumvent the following restriction with a predicate by allowing partial continuity by further restricting the given range.. 

> A discrete domain always represents the entire set of values of its type; it cannot represent partial domains such as "prime integers" or "strings of length 5." So you cannot, for example, construct a DiscreteDomain to view a set of days in a range, with a JODA DateTime that includes times up to the second: because this would not contain all elements of the type.

https://gist.github.com/TuomasKiviaho/2ccfa28d26956c46fa8ec70c6c37cb97

title: Rejuvenate logging statement levels

labels.name: type=other
labels.description: Miscellaneous activities not covered by other type= labels

body:
## Introduction

We are in the process of evaluating our [research prototype Eclipse plug-in](https://github.com/ponder-lab/Logging-Level-Evolution-Plugin) that "rejuvenates" log statement levels based on how "interesting" the enclosing methods are to the developers. The assumption is that methods that are worked on more and more recently by developers should have higher log levels (e.g., INFO as compared to FINEST). Our end goal is to reduce information overload, as well as alleviate developers from manually making log level changes.

The transformation decision is made by analyzing the "degree of interest" (DOI) values of enclosing methods for logging invocations. DOI value is a kind of real number for a program element which shows how developers are interested in it. It is computed from the interaction events between developer and element, such as developer edits the element. In this project, we compute the DOI using the project's git history.

We are looking for feedback on our tool from developers. If you can, we would appreciate if you can **comment on each of the transformations** in the case that this PR is not accepted. Of course, we would also love to contribute to your project.

## Transformed Logging Statements

Here is a list of DOI values for enclosing methods of transformed log invocations in your projects:

log expression | original log level | transformed log level | type FQN | enclosing method | DOI value
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
logger.log(Level.FINE,"Service   {0} has terminated. Previous state was: {1}",new Object[]{service,from}) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.util.concurrent.ServiceManager$ServiceListener | terminated(com.google.common.util.concurrent.Service.State) | 0
logger.log(Level.FINE,"Starting   {0}.",service) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.util.concurrent.ServiceManager$ServiceListener | starting() | 0
logger.log(Level.FINE,"Started {0}   in {1}.",new Object[]{service,stopwatch}) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.util.concurrent.ServiceManager$ServiceManagerState | transitionService(com.google.common.util.concurrent.Service,com.google.common.util.concurrent.Service.State,com.google.common.util.concurrent.Service.State) | 0
logger.fine(" Testing: " +   name) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.collect.testing.PerCollectionSizeTestSuiteBuilder | createTestSuite() | 0
logger.fine("Expanded: " +   formatFeatureSet(features)) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.collect.testing.FeatureSpecificTestSuiteBuilder | createTestSuite() | 0
logger.log(Level.INFO,"message",EXCEPTION) | INFO | FINEST | com.google.common.testing.TestLogHandlerTest$ExampleClassUnderTest | foo() | 0
logger.fine(" Testing: " +   name) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.collect.testing.FeatureSpecificTestSuiteBuilder | createTestSuite() | 0
logger.fine("   Sizes: " +   formatFeatureSet(sizesToTest)) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.collect.testing.PerCollectionSizeTestSuiteBuilder | createTestSuite() | 0
logger.fine("Features: " +   formatFeatureSet(features)) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.collect.testing.FeatureSpecificTestSuiteBuilder | createTestSuite() | 0
logger.finer(Platform.format("%s:   excluding because it was explicitly suppressed.",test)) | FINER | FINEST | com.google.common.collect.testing.FeatureSpecificTestSuiteBuilder | matches(junit.framework.Test) | 0



##  Manual Change 
This pull request contains one manual change where we changed (please see below) adjusted a test case to reflect our change. This is not part of the output of our tool but simply a necessary change to make the test pass.

```diff
diff --git a/guava-testlib/test/com/google/common/testing/TestLogHandlerTest.java b/guava-testlib/test/com/google/common/testing/TestLogHandlerTest.java
index 678f1ea4b..9ca57fab7 100644
--- a/guava-testlib/test/com/google/common/testing/TestLogHandlerTest.java
+++ b/guava-testlib/test/com/google/common/testing/TestLogHandlerTest.java
@@ -56,7 +56,7 @@ public class TestLogHandlerTest extends TestCase {
     assertTrue(handler.getStoredLogRecords().isEmpty());
     ExampleClassUnderTest.foo();
     LogRecord record = handler.getStoredLogRecords().get(0);
-    assertEquals(Level.INFO, record.getLevel());
+    assertEquals(Level.FINEST, record.getLevel());
     assertEquals("message", record.getMessage());
     assertSame(EXCEPTION, record.getThrown());
   }
```

## Bug Fix

We found a bug in the same test case where only log messages having level `INFO` or above are tested. Now, all levels are tested. This was also a manual fix.

## Settings

We have several settings to analyze these DOI values. The settings we are using in this pull request are:
- Treat  CONFIG/WARNING/SEVERE level as a category and not a traditional level, i.e., our tool ignores CONFIG/WARNING/SEVERE log level (setting 1).
- Never lower the logging level of logging statements within catch blocks (setting 2).
- The number of commits evaluated: 1000 (setting 3).

Head: 74fc49f

We can vary these settings and rerun our if you desire.

## DOI Intervals

For your information, we also generate a list of DOI value intervals. Given this list, our tool could rejuvenate log levels by knowing which intervals the DOI values of enclosing methods for log invocations are in:

subject | DOI boundary | log level
-- | -- | --
guava | [0.0, 0.8812485) | FINEST
guava | [0.8812485, 1.762497) | FINER
guava | [1.762497, 2.6437454) | FINE
guava | [2.6437454, 3.524994) | INFO
guava-gwt | [0.0, 0.30324998) | FINEST
guava-gwt | [0.30324998, 0.60649997) | FINER
guava-gwt | [0.60649997, 0.90975) | FINE
guava-gwt | [0.90975, 1.2129999) | INFO
guava-testlib | [0.0, 2.8239996) | FINEST
guava-testlib | [2.8239996, 5.6479993) | FINER
guava-testlib | [5.6479993, 8.471999) | FINE

title: Rejuvenate log levels
body:
## Introduction

We are in the process of evaluating our [research prototype Eclipse plug-in](https://github.com/ponder-lab/Logging-Level-Evolution-Plugin) that "rejuvenates" log statement levels based on how "interesting" the enclosing methods are to the developers. The assumption is that methods that are worked on more and more recently by developers should have higher log levels (e.g., INFO as compared to FINEST). Our end goal is to reduce information overload, as well as alleviate developers from manually making log level changes.

The transformation decision is made by analyzing the "degree of interest" (DOI) values of enclosing methods for logging invocations. DOI value is a kind of real number for a program element which shows how developers are interested in it. It is computed from the interaction events between developer and element, such as developer edits the element. In this project, we compute the DOI using the project's git history.

We are looking for feedback on our tool from developers. If you can, we would appreciate if you can **comment on each of the transformations** in the case that this PR is not accepted. Of course, we would also love to contribute to your project.

## Transformed Logging Statements

Here is a list of DOI values for enclosing methods of transformed log invocations in your projects:

log expression | original log level | transformed log level | type FQN | enclosing method | DOI value
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
logger.log(Level.FINE,"Service   {0} has terminated. Previous state was: {1}",new Object[]{service,from}) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.util.concurrent.ServiceManager$ServiceListener | terminated(com.google.common.util.concurrent.Service.State) | 0
logger.log(Level.FINE,"Starting   {0}.",service) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.util.concurrent.ServiceManager$ServiceListener | starting() | 0
logger.log(Level.FINE,"Started {0}   in {1}.",new Object[]{service,stopwatch}) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.util.concurrent.ServiceManager$ServiceManagerState | transitionService(com.google.common.util.concurrent.Service,com.google.common.util.concurrent.Service.State,com.google.common.util.concurrent.Service.State) | 0
logger.fine(" Testing: " +   name) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.collect.testing.PerCollectionSizeTestSuiteBuilder | createTestSuite() | 0
logger.fine("Expanded: " +   formatFeatureSet(features)) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.collect.testing.FeatureSpecificTestSuiteBuilder | createTestSuite() | 0
logger.log(Level.INFO,"message",EXCEPTION) | INFO | FINEST | com.google.common.testing.TestLogHandlerTest$ExampleClassUnderTest | foo() | 0
logger.fine(" Testing: " +   name) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.collect.testing.FeatureSpecificTestSuiteBuilder | createTestSuite() | 0
logger.fine("   Sizes: " +   formatFeatureSet(sizesToTest)) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.collect.testing.PerCollectionSizeTestSuiteBuilder | createTestSuite() | 0
logger.fine("Features: " +   formatFeatureSet(features)) | FINE | FINEST | com.google.common.collect.testing.FeatureSpecificTestSuiteBuilder | createTestSuite() | 0
logger.finer(Platform.format("%s:   excluding because it was explicitly suppressed.",test)) | FINER | FINEST | com.google.common.collect.testing.FeatureSpecificTestSuiteBuilder | matches(junit.framework.Test) | 0



##  Manual Change 
This pull request contains one manual change where we changed (please see below) adjusted a test case to reflect our change. This is not part of the output of our tool but simply a necessary change to make the test pass.

```diff
diff --git a/guava-testlib/test/com/google/common/testing/TestLogHandlerTest.java b/guava-testlib/test/com/google/common/testing/TestLogHandlerTest.java
index 678f1ea4b..9ca57fab7 100644
--- a/guava-testlib/test/com/google/common/testing/TestLogHandlerTest.java
+++ b/guava-testlib/test/com/google/common/testing/TestLogHandlerTest.java
@@ -56,7 +56,7 @@ public class TestLogHandlerTest extends TestCase {
     assertTrue(handler.getStoredLogRecords().isEmpty());
     ExampleClassUnderTest.foo();
     LogRecord record = handler.getStoredLogRecords().get(0);
-    assertEquals(Level.INFO, record.getLevel());
+    assertEquals(Level.FINEST, record.getLevel());
     assertEquals("message", record.getMessage());
     assertSame(EXCEPTION, record.getThrown());
   }
```

## Bug Fix

We found a bug in the same test case where only log messages having level `INFO` or above are tested. Now, all levels are tested. This was also a manual fix.

## Settings

We have several settings to analyze these DOI values. The settings we are using in this pull request are:
- Treat  CONFIG/WARNING/SEVERE level as a category and not a traditional level, i.e., our tool ignores CONFIG/WARNING/SEVERE log level (setting 1).
- Never lower the logging level of logging statements within catch blocks (setting 2).
- The number of commits evaluated: 1000 (setting 3).

Head: 74fc49f

We can vary these settings and rerun our if you desire.

## DOI Intervals

For your information, we also generate a list of DOI value intervals. Given this list, our tool could rejuvenate log levels by knowing which intervals the DOI values of enclosing methods for log invocations are in:

subject | DOI boundary | log level
-- | -- | --
guava | [0.0, 0.8812485) | FINEST
guava | [0.8812485, 1.762497) | FINER
guava | [1.762497, 2.6437454) | FINE
guava | [2.6437454, 3.524994) | INFO
guava-gwt | [0.0, 0.30324998) | FINEST
guava-gwt | [0.30324998, 0.60649997) | FINER
guava-gwt | [0.60649997, 0.90975) | FINE
guava-gwt | [0.90975, 1.2129999) | INFO
guava-testlib | [0.0, 2.8239996) | FINEST
guava-testlib | [2.8239996, 5.6479993) | FINER
guava-testlib | [5.6479993, 8.471999) | FINE
guava-testlib | [8.471999, 11.295999) | INFO
guava-tests | [0.0, 1.4872494) | FINEST
guava-tests | [1.4872494, 2.9744987) | FINER
guava-tests | [2.9744987, 4.461748) | FINE
guava-tests | [4.461748, 5.9489975) | INFO

title: Initialize uninterruptibles with current interrupt state of thread

labels.name: type=enhancement
labels.description: Make an existing feature better

body: If a thread comes into Uninterruptibles already in an interrupted state, the first call to the target action will immediately fail with InterruptedException.  Initialize the 'interrupted' flag with the current state of the thread so that the first attempt can complete (assuming the thread is not interrupted again immediately after the initialization).

title: method getClassPathEntries create File objects from URL encoded string (with %20 instead of spaces)
body:
method  _com.google.common.reflect.ClassPath:getClassPathEntries(ClassLoader classloader)_ 
Guava 19, Windows 10, Java 8.
At line 392: File object is created from string `entry.getFile()` 
where entry is URL object from URLClassLoader
`File file = new File(entry.getFile())`  

Method _URL.getFile()_ returns absolute file path URL encoded (ex.: 

> "/C:/Program%20Files/Java/jdk1.8.0_201/jre/lib/ext/access-bridge-64.jar"

)
File object constructor interprets URL encoded characters literally, therefore this file doesnt exists.

Possible solution to use method _URL.toURI()_:
`line 392: File file = new File(entry.toURI()); `

When File(URI uri) constructor is used, it uses _URI.getPath()_ method internally, and it handles URL encoding characters properly.

title: Dead link in Javadoc for HashFunction
body:
The Javadoc for HashFunction says:

> We have published microbenchmark results for many common hash functions.

And "microbenchmark results" is a link... to the anchor noWeHaventYet. I'd suggest that either such benchmarks should be published and linked, or the suggestion that they have should be removed from the Javadoc.

For fun, I went back through the history of that file, and this link has been there since the hash package was open-sourced in Guava 11, some 7 years ago.

title: Concurrent (atomic) access to ByteBuffers

labels.name: type=addition
labels.description: A new feature

body:
I'd like to see utilities/wrappers for getting good concurrent (atomic) access to ByteBuffers. I've been reading [these posts](http://psy-lob-saw.blogspot.com/2013/07/atomicity-of-unaligned-memory-access-in.html) and they're a little bit old but I don't see any reason why they aren't still accurate - especially on older CPUs.

ByteBuffers are very interesting because I believe they can provide the experience and performance of manual memory management in Java. but some way to access concurrency primitives would be necessary to make it practical. Additionally, Java's JIT might be able to runtime-optimize some algorithms based on constant inputs so it'd be faster than the native equivalents, and it'd also be faster than going through the JNI. This is very use-case-specific tho so not something that can be relied on.

But yeah. I just want to port some high-performance libraries to Java and I don't feel like trying to fine-tune Java implementations when I can just convert the original.

body: I've been using CharMatcher.javaDigit() for a long time and it has never given me any issues.  I think it's a step in the wrong direction to force people to say CharMatcher.inRange('0', '9') because it is making an extremely common use-case more difficult.

title: inferred type does not conform to upper bound(s)
Deduplicate common logic in Uninterruptibles class, avoiding allocations

labels.name: type=enhancement
labels.description: Make an existing feature better

body:
I recently came across [this discussion](https://github.com/google/guava/issues/2384#issuecomment-181137856) around the reason for having duplicated logic in `Uninterruptibles`, and am offering this as an approach which avoids per-method call allocations and reflection. There is some overhead in terms of class count though, apologies if this was already discounted for that reason.

Also related: #1409

title: Document the JDK 9+ alternative to `Maps#immutableEntry`

labels.name: type=api-docs
labels.description: Change/add API documentation

body:
I think this suggestion is worthwhile for two reasons:
- The JDK 9+ alternative is null-hostile, fully in line with Guava's philosophy. (In fact, my colleagues and I were surprised to learn that `Maps.immutableEntry` allows nulls.)
- The excellent arguments in favour of `Immutable*` types put forth in #2969 do not hold here, since `Maps.immutableEntry` does not have a special return type that communicates its immutability.

title: Document the JDK 9+ alternatives to `Preconditions#{checkElementIndex,checkPositionIndexes}`

labels.name: type=api-docs
labels.description: Change/add API documentation

body:
Analogous to #3382 and #3383. I can imagine these two suggestions will cause some debate, since they have overloads that accept a `@Nullable String desc` for which there is no counterpart in the standard library.

One way to settle the debate could be to benchmark whether the JDK builtins are more efficient. (`Objects#checkIndex` is annotated `@ForceInline` and delegates to a `@HotSpotIntrinsicCandidate`, so it may be.)

title: LocalCache is locked when computing element weight
body: When using the `CacheBuilder` and specifying a weigher, the current solution assumes that the weigher code is fast as the entire cache is locked when the weigher code is evaluated https://github.com/google/guava/blob/master/guava/src/com/google/common/cache/LocalCache.java#L2009. For weigher functions that are not fast, this leads to the entire cache being locked for the entire duration. It seems to me that it should be fine to computer the weight without the cache structure being locked, and only lock it once the weight has been computed.

title: Add Support For Calendar Instance in MoreObjects#toStringHelper()

labels.name: type=enhancement
labels.description: Make an existing feature better

body:
Currently there is not handling for ```java.util.Calendar``` in ```MoreObjects#toStringHelper()```. So when I try to add ```Calendar``` instance in ```toStringHelper()```, it print default String return from Calendar instance, which is very bad. For example, if I try the following-
```
public String toString() {
    return MoreObjects.toStringHelper(this)
            .add("name", name)
            .add("beginDate", beginDate)
            .add("endDate", endDate)
            .toString();
```
It return something like below-
```
SearchRequest{name=test, beginDate=java.util.GregorianCalendar[time=1548050448000,areFieldsSet=true,areAllFieldsSet=true,lenient=true,zone=sun.util.calendar.ZoneInfo[id="Asia/Dhaka",offset=21600000,dstSavings=0,useDaylight=false,transitions=8,lastRule=null],firstDayOfWeek=1,minimalDaysInFirstWeek=1,ERA=1,YEAR=2019,MONTH=0,WEEK_OF_YEAR=4,WEEK_OF_MONTH=4,DAY_OF_MONTH=21,DAY_OF_YEAR=21,DAY_OF_WEEK=2,DAY_OF_WEEK_IN_MONTH=3,AM_PM=1,HOUR=0,HOUR_OF_DAY=12,MINUTE=0,SECOND=48,MILLISECOND=0,ZONE_OFFSET=21600000,DST_OFFSET=0], endDate=null}
```
Which is not readable at all. It will be good to print some user friendly formatted Calendar instance, or there should be some way to configure ```Calendar``` or any type.

title: add wiki link from graph documentation to JGraphT adapter

labels.name: type=documentation
labels.description: Documentation that is other than for an API

body:
As part of the JGraphT project, we've developed adapters which allow a Guava Graph to be viewed as a JGraphT graph, making it possible to run JGraphT algorithms against it:

https://jgrapht.org/guide/GuavaAdapter

Developers who prefer using Guava Graph for its user-friendliness (or other reasons) may want to take advantage of the rich library of algorithms provided by JGraphT; the adapters make this easy.

Currently, the Guava Graph wiki has a section which mentions JGraphT:

https://github.com/google/guava/wiki/GraphsExplained#why-should-i-use-it-instead-of-something-else

So it might make sense to add the adapter link there.

title: EndpointPair.Unordered#equals too tricky?
body:
Maybe I'm terribly wrong, but why not to replace

https://github.com/google/guava/blob/f15fdd10cd1e3e81ad2c31f555dfaaf70a72cf69/guava/src/com/google/common/graph/EndpointPair.java#L227-L239

with
```java
return nodeU().equals(other.nodeU()) && nodeV().equals(other.nodeV())
    || nodeU().equals(other.nodeV()) && nodeV().equals(other.nodeU());
```
?

This is of course nothing else but uncommented / inlined https://github.com/google/guava/blob/f15fdd10cd1e3e81ad2c31f555dfaaf70a72cf69/guava/src/com/google/common/graph/EndpointPair.java#L230.
I was analyzing referred comments over and over to make sure that I really, really understand what's going on (is this tricky part hiding somewhere?). I think that I am, but who knows?

You know better than me that
- "&&" has higher precedence than "||", so no brackets required (https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/operators.html)
- "&&" and "||" exhibit "short-circuiting" behavior, so no nesting needed  (https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/op2.html)

I believe that proposed change will make `equals` code slightly more readable... and that I'm not as dumb as to miss something here.

title: Consider adding an implies method to Booleans
body:
Say I want to check whether `!exists` implies `!hasContent`, these being two `boolean` variables.

Currently I must call: `Preconditions.checkState(exists || !hasContent)`, which I find very difficult to understand when reading it after the fact. I feel the urge to add a comment: `/** Checks that not exists implies not hasContent. **/`

In order to make my code auto-documented, I prefer to add a one-line method in a utility class: `public static boolean implies(boolean a, boolean b)`, that returns `!a || b`.

Then the check above reads `Preconditions.checkState(implies(!exists, !hasContent))`. A much clearer statement, I would say.

Would you please consider adding such a method where appropriate, perhaps in `Booleans`?

body: The documentation for the ```CharMatcher.countIn``` method does not state the expected behaviour if the input sequence is ```null```. The user may expect the method to return 0 for such a case but the implementation throws NullPointerException (which could also be considered as a valid output). This ambiguity should be explicitly clarified in the documentation or else handled well in the code.

title: Support for low surrogate values in checking for pattern
body:
```
Predicate<CharSequence> sample = Predicates.contains(Pattern.compile("\uD840")); 
assertTrue(sample.apply("\uD840\uDC01")); //gives violation, \uDC01 is low surrogate
assertTrue(sample.apply("\uD840\uDBFF")); //no violation, \uDBFF is high surrogate
```

There is an assertion violation due to the presence of \uDC01 (which is in the range of low surrogate characters) in the string. However, replacing it with other characters (including high surrogates) the function works fine.

title: AbstractFuture.setFuture(...) return value semantics
body:
Apologies if I'm mistaken about this. It's kind of subtle and might be inconsequential, but I'm wondering whether it's correct to return `false` in the case that the receiving future is already cancelled and the cancellation gets successfully propagated to the provided future.

I think of `false` as indicating the action "failed" and had no effect, but in this case it did have an effect (essentially successfully "binding" the fate of the two futures as is the purpose of the method), and could be considered a success.

Another way to look at it is that concurrency-wise it's essentially the same as the case where the recieving future isn't initially cancelled so the `setFuture` "succeeds", but is cancelled immediately after by some other thread, prior to that `setFuture` invocation returning `true`. The difference between the two cases just depends on the winner of that cancellation race, and the outcome and final state in each case is identical, but in one it returns `false` and the other `true`.
